results.headline: It’s Not All in His Head; He Actually Is a Mess
results.display_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III

results.summary_short: “A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III” stars Charlie Sheen as a graphic designer who wants to win back his true love.

results.headline: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, All Brought to Life by Inmates

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Caesar Must Die

results.summary_short: “Caesar Must Die” sets Shakespeare’s play in an Italian prison, using inmates to tell the tale of politics and power.

results.headline: Unemployed Adman Makes a Deal With His Body

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Luck Would Have It

results.summary_short: Álex de la Iglesia’s “As Luck Would Have It” examines marketing and morality through a dejected, unemployed adman.

results.headline: It’ll Be a Mixed Marriage: Just One of Them Is Alive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warm Bodies

results.summary_short: In “Warm Bodies” zombie meets girl. Zombie loses girl. Zombie — well, you know the rest, though here the familiar balance comes with human tartare.

results.headline: An Insistent Voice From Behind Bars

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mumia: Long Distance Revolutionary

results.summary_short: The documentary “Mumia,” directed by Stephen Vittoria, revisits the case of Mumia Abu-Jamal, convicted of killing a police officer, and highlights the writing he has done in prison.

results.headline: Hizzoner on Screen: Regrets? That’s Not His Style

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Koch

results.summary_short: A documentary about Edward I. Koch, mayor of New York during troubled years, examines his city as well as his personality.

results.headline: Addictive ‘Soy Sauce’ With Ruinous Power

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of John Dies at the End

results.summary_short: “John Dies at the End,” directed by Don Coscarelli, is part stoner comedy, part gutbucket horror and part sci-fi allegory.

results.headline: Taking Back the Night, Slasher Style

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girls Against Boys

results.summary_short: In “Girls Against Boys” men are pigs, women are sick of it, and revenge-fueled death and dismemberment pass for feminist critique.

results.headline: Bad, Badder and Baddest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bullet To The Head

results.summary_short: Walter Hill’s action film “Bullet to the Head” stars Sylvester Stallone as a contract killer in New Orleans.

results.headline: Always Carrying a Big Stick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Gladiators

results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Last Gladiators,” Alex Gibney Shows the tough-guy caste in hockey.

results.headline: Rock Star Toasts the Glory Days of Analog

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sound City

results.summary_short: “Sound City,” a documentary by Dave Grohl, looks at a recording studio in the San Fernando Valley that flourished in the 1970s but faded with the onset of the digital revolution.

results.headline: A Twist on Grimm: It’s the Witches Who are Hunted

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters

results.summary_short: Hansel and Gretel, all grown up and perhaps traumatized by their childhood, use their fury against their captor to help others.

results.headline: Tiny Actress, a Spare Script and Huge Revelations

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nana

results.summary_short: “Nana,” a French film by Valérie Massadian, sees the world through the eyes of a 4-year-old girl on a farm.

results.headline: Leaving ‘Death in Venice’ to Choose Life in Tel Aviv

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yossi

results.summary_short: In “Yossi,” by Eytan Fox, a closeted Tel Aviv doctor finds a new lease on life after the death of his lover.

results.headline: Siberian Hunters in Their Element
results.display_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy People: A Year in the Taiga

results.summary_short: Werner Herzog’s “Happy People: A Year in the Taiga” is a seasonal portrait focusing on fur trappers in the vast Siberian taiga.

results.headline: A Big Nest, Bursting With a Family’s Vices

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Taste of Money

results.summary_short: Most of “The Taste of Money” takes place in the palatial home of a Korean family whose wealth, influence and corruption approach Borgiaesque dimensions.

results.headline: In an Indie Drama, the Real Drama Is Behind the Scenes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Supporting Characters

results.summary_short: “Supporting Characters” delves into the twists and turns in the lives of a film-editing team.

results.headline: Violence and Thievery Find Room for Honor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Parker

results.summary_short: Jennifer Lopez and Jason Statham star in “Parker,” where action and revenge are central to the plot.

results.headline: Whipping Blades to Sharpen Politics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knife Fight

results.summary_short: Rob Lowe stars as a political operative in “Knife Fight,” directed by Bill Guttentag.

results.headline: Microcosm of Society, Seeking an Anchor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La pirogue

results.summary_short: “The Pirogue” is the story of 30 men and one woman who set off in a long, brightly painted wooden canoe on a voyage from Africa to Spain.
